metadata.title: Three-phase PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure: Fabrication, characterization and investigation of microwave absorption and EMI shielding of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs/epoxy hybrid composite

sections.text:
M AN
AC CE
PT ED
In this work, a three phase carbon fiber (CF)-based electromagnetic (EM) wave absorbing and
EM interference (EMI) shielding heterostructure was fabricated through a layer by layer
assembly. The nano-Fe3O4 particles were deposited on CFs via a modified multi-step electrophoretic deposition (EPD). The PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructures were prepared using an in situ polymerization process of polyaniline (PANI) on nano-Fe3O4@CFs in HCl solution. The results showed that the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats with a layer by layer (LBL) assembly were successfully fabricated. The saturated magnetization (Ms) of the as-synthesized
nano-Fe3O4 powder decreased from 72.612 emu/g to 8.934 emu/g for the nano-Fe3O4@CFs and ∗ E-mail address of corresponding author: faridmovy@gmail.com Tel&fax: +982182884390
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
from 8.934 emu/g to 0.191 emu/g for the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats due to the reduction in the effective mass/volume percentage of nano-Fe3O4 particles in the composites. The fabricated epoxy-based hybrid composites filled with PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs segments exhibited both of the dielectric and magnetic losses at the 8.2-18 GHz frequency range. The composite containing
1 wt.% of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs with the thickness of 1.5 mm showed a maximum reflection loss (RL) value of -11.11 dB with an effective absorption bandwidth of about 6 GHz in the
frequency range of 8.2-18 GHz. Also, the sample filled with 5 wt. % of EM wave absorbing
segments with the thickness of 3 mm demonstrated an EMI shielding effectiveness (SE) value of
29 dB at the same frequency range.
Keywords: A. Carbon fibers, A. Hybrid composites, A. Nano particles, B. Magnetic properties,
Electrophoretic deposition.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the explosive development of electronic industries and wide-spreading use of wireless
technologies in advanced devices such as smartphones, laptops, tablets and etc., the
electromagnetic (EM) wave radiation pollution has known to be an important global issue since
it can affect the performance of sensitive electronic devices and also be harmful to human health
[1-6]. Therefore, EM wave absorbing and also EM interference (EMI) shielding materials have
gained much attention among researchers of different countries in recent years. Hence, a wide
range of materials such as, magnetic nano-powders (Fe3O4 [5-8], NiFe2O4 [9-11] MnFe2O4 [12, 13] FeCo [14, 15] and CoFe2O4 [1, 9, 16]), dielectric nano-particles (BaTiO3 [17, 18] and ZnO [5, 19]), carbon-based materials (CFs [1, 16, 20-27], carbon black [28, 29], carbon nano tubes
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
(CNTs) [2, 3, 5, 7] and graphene [2, 8, 13, 19, 30]) and conductive polymers (polyaniline (PANI)
[1, 7, 8, 12], polypyrrole (PPy) [31-34] and polyacetylene [35, 36]) have been introduced for EM
wave absorption applications.
Among magnetic materials, magnetic iron oxide or Fe3O4 nano-particles owing to their exceptional properties including, non-toxic nature, simple and low-cost production, appropriate
energy loss, adjustable magnetic properties and strong spin polarization [6, 7, 20, 28] along with
carbon-based materials due to their excellent EM wave attenuation performance, higher specific
surface area, light weight, good chemical stability, superior mechanical strength and higher
electrical conductivity have obtained great interest in the scope of EM wave absorbing composite
fabrication [37]. Furthermore, relatively low price and ease of use makes CFs as a cost-effective
and high-performance material in comparison with other carbon-based materials for this
application [1, 20]. However, it is well-known that the very high electrical conductivity of CFs (~107 S/m [20]) typically leads to an increase in the impedance mismatch between air and the
surface of CF-based EM wave absorbing composites which result in the reflection of a huge
portion of the incident wave [1, 20, 37].
The main mechanisms of EM wave absorption in magnetic materials are magnetic losses such as
hysteresis, electron spin resonance and domain wall resonance [38]. Additionally, magnetic
materials with relatively higher electrical conductivity exhibit great conduction losses [20].
Moreover, the two most important loss mechanisms of non-magnetic materials such as carbon-
based materials and also conductive polymers are dielectric (dipolar) and conduction losses.
Conduction losses typically dominate in high conductivity materials and dipolar losses dominate
in low conductivity materials [38]. Therefore, high performance in EM wave absorption and
EMI shielding can be achieved when an absorbing composite exhibits both of magnetic and
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
dielectric loss mechanism together [5]. Consequently, the fabrication of CF-based EM wave
absorbing composites including the CFs which are decorated with magnetic materials (especially
nano-Fe3O4 particles) has attracted considerable attention in recent years.
Within the scope of the fabrication of CFs-based structures containing nano-Fe3O4 particles, Xu et al.[39], prepared nano-Fe3O4@CFs composite using sol-gel method. They reported a successful covering of CFs with a coating layer of 800 nm thickness containing nano-Fe3O4 particles with the average size of 30 nm. In another study, Osouli-Bostanabad et al.[23],
produced Fe/Fe3O4@CFs composites by chemical electrodeposition process for EM wave absorption applications. They found that, the Fe/Fe3O4 films prepared at 80 °C with the optimum deposition time of 4 min formed a uniform and dense structure, and were composed of very fine
globular nano-Fe3O4 particles with average size of 50 nm. With the same method, Meng et al.[22], synthesized nano-Fe3O4@CFs composites. They reported that unlike the deposited Fe3O4 films at 75 °C which were uniform with a dense microstructure, the films deposited at 60 °C
were continuous and rough. In a similar work, Qiang et al. [24], reported the wet chemical
deposition of nano-F3O4 on CFs and obtained homogenous composites with the coercivity and saturation magnetization of 166.7 Oe and 39.2 emu/g, respectively. In addition to above-
mentioned works, the electrophoretic deposition (EPD) method, due to its exceptional features
such as simple, cost-effective and environmentally friendly procedure, high rate of production,
easy adjustability and ability in the deposition of uniform and high-quality coatings [40], has
been recently introduced as a promising technique to fabricate nano-Fe3O4@CFs composites. In the scope of EM wave absorbing materials, Salimkhani et al.[25], reported the fabrication of
nano-Fe3O4@CFs composites using conventional EPD process. They indicated that, the morphology of the surface of the nano-Fe3O4@CFs produced by EPD was uniform, dense and
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
smooth enough compared to that of the composites synthesized with other deposition techniques.
In another study, Gholampour et al.[20], fabricated nano-Fe3O4@CFs composites using a modified multi-step EPD process. They concluded that, the uniformity of deposited nano-Fe3O4 layers on CFs was remarkably improved as a result of the comprehensive particle movements
during modified multi-step EPD process.
The overall objective of the above-mentioned works and also many studies in the field of EM
wave absorbing materials fabrication would be to increase the wave absorption performance of
composites without improving its effective absorption bandwidth. It seems that covering the
surface of EM wave absorbing composites with a layer of conductive polymers can enhance their
effective absorption bandwidth [41]. Therefore, in this work, considering the unique properties
of nano-Fe3O4, CFs and EPD process and also superior features of PANI (such as higher flexibility, very light weight and facile processibility [12]), a three-phase PANI@nano-
Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure was designed and produced to enhance the EM wave absorption properties of nano-Fe3O4@CFs composites. Herein, the CFs were firstly covered with a layer of nano-Fe3O4 particles using a modified multi-step EPD process. Then, a layer of PANI was produced on nano-Fe3O4@CFs composite through the in situ polymerization process of aniline. The structural, morphological, magnetic, electromagnetic, EM wave absorption and EMI
shielding properties of the epoxy-based PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composite were also investigated in details.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and method
sections.text:
2.1. Materials
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
The ammonium per sulfate (APS) (98%), aniline monomer (99.5 %), ethanol (96%), acetone
(99%), ammonium hydroxide (33%), iodine (99.8%), FeCl3.6H2O (99.9%), HNO3 (65%) and HCl (37%) supplied by Merck company, FeSO4.7H2O (99%) supplied by Sigma Aldrich company, pan-based CFs (D=7 µm) supplied by Chongqing Joywell Trade company, epoxy 828 (Viscosity in 25 °C=1.75 MPa.S and Density in 25 °C =1.16 g/cm3) and its hardener (Viscosity in 25°C=1.1 MPa.S and Density in 25°C =1 g/cm3) supplied by Hexion company were all
purchased and used without further purification.
2.2. Synthesis of nano-Fe3O4 particles
In order to prepare the nano-Fe3O4 particles, simple and economical chemical co-precipitation method was used. Distilled water was used to make all the solutions. Initially, a 1 M aqueous
FeSO4 (40 ml) solution was mixed with a 1 M aqueous FeCl3 (80 ml) solution in a four-neck flask under a nitrogen atmosphere. Then, ammonium hydroxide solution (about 120 ml) was
slowly added with mechanical stirring until a pH about 12 was achieved. Vigorous mechanical
stirring was continued for another hour. The solution colour could be observed altering from
brown to black (nano-Fe3O4 particles are black). Then, the formed nano-Fe3O4 particles were separated by applying a permanent external magnet. To centrifuge the nano-Fe3O4 particles distilled water was then added and was done in triplets eliminate all remained pollutions. Finally,
the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 particles were washed with acetone twice and dispersed in acetone and kept in a dry and clean vial [20].
2.3. Preparation of EPD suspension
In order to create the driving force of EPD process, 10 mg of iodine was dissolved in 100 ml
acetone as the surfactant to produce positive surface charge on the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
particles. Then, the suspensions were prepared after dispersion of 50 mg of as-synthesized nano-
Fe3O4 powder in the prepared solutions using mechanical stirring. After mechanically stirring for 30 min, to improve the stability of suspensions, they were stabilized ultrasonically for another 30
min.
2.4. Preparation of EPD electrodes
The pan-based CFs were chosen as the cathode of EPD process. To improve the adhesion of
nano-Fe3O4 particles on CFs, they were etched with a nitric acid solution for 4 hours at room temperature and then washed with distilled water and dried for 2 days at room temperature. An
AISI 316L stainless steel (SS) thin foil was used as the anode of EPD. To enhance the quality of
deposition process, the SS anode was shaped to a cylindrical tube with the diameter and length of
5 and 10 cm, respectively. Then, the anode was located in a 100 ml beaker and the CFs were
placed in the center of the beaker and anode with a glass holder. The distance between the anode
and CFs was set to be 2 cm.
2.5. Electrophoretic deposition process
The EPD processes were carried out using a direct current (DC) power supply with a constant voltage of 25 V. The current density during the EPD process was about 15 mA.cm-2. In order to
increase the performance of EPD process, all CFs were electrophoretically coated twice. The
time of each deposition process was set to be 10 min. After EPD processes, to remove all
agglomerations, the CFs were rinsed with acetone and distilled water and dried for 24 hours at
room temperature. A schematic illustration of EPD setup and process is shown in Fig. 1.
2.6. Preparation of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
At first, 1.14 mL of aniline monomer and 1.87 g of APS were each dissolved separately in each
25 mL of 0.5 M HCl solution. Then, the nano-Fe3O4@CFs were cut into the short segments (0.4- 0.5 cm in length) and immersed in the solution containing contains aniline monomer and
vigorously stirred for 30 min at 0 °C. Then, the APS solution was slowly drop-wised and the
mixture was mechanically stirred for 3 hours. For the last step, the fabricated PANI@nano-
Fe3O4@CFs mats were washed with 0.5 M HCl solution and distilled water and kept at 90 °C for about 8 hours. A schematic illustration of PANI polymerization process and fabricated
PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats are shown in Fig. 1.
2.6. Characterizations
The morphological studies of the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 powder, nano-Fe3O4@CFs and PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructures were carried out using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, Philips CM30), X-ray diffraction method (XRD, X’Pert MPD
system, Philips, λCukα1=0.154 nm) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Tescan, Mira 3). The chemical properties of samples were studied using X-ray photoelectron
spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 220i-XL, Thermo-VG), fourier transforms infra-red
spectroscopy (FT-IR, PerkinElmer Spectrum system) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy
(EDS). The magnetic properties of samples were determined using vibrating sample
magnetometer (VSM, C300) at room temperature. To investigate the electromagnetic properties
of samples, the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats were cut into the short pieces (0.2–0.5 mm in length), then 0.03 g of chopped PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs were mixed with a certain amount of epoxy 828 with vigorous mechanical agitation. Thereafter, the mixtures were cast into the rectangular molds with the dimensions of 10.16×22.86×5 mm3 for 8.2-12.4 GHz (X-band) and
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
7.90× 15.80×5 mm3 for 12.4-18 GHz (Ku-band). After drying, the samples were separated and
grounded with SiC sandpapers from #1000-#5000 and polished with 0.1 µm Al2O3 suspension to mirror finishing. To increase the fitting between waveguides and the samples, their walls were
also grounded by sandpapers. The dimensions of samples were accurately measured by a precise
Vernier caliper. The used sample holders for testing were standard WR90 (X-band) and WR62
(Ku-band) waveguides. In order to determine the best EM wave absorption performance, five
hybrid composite samples with the thicknesses of 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5 and 3 mm (both of the X and Ku
bands samples with the similar thickness are considered as one sample) were fabricated for
which the weight ratio of chopped PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs to epoxy 828 was set to be 1:100 and also five other samples with the similar thicknesses were fabricated when the weight ratio of
chopped PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs to epoxy 828 was set to be 1:20. The electromagnetic properties, EM wave absorption and also EMI shielding effectiveness (SE) of the hybrid
composite samples were measured using a vector network analyzer (VNA, HP 8720 Network
Analyzer) at room temperature. To calculating complex permittivity and permeability Nicolson-
Ross-Weir algorithm was used. The errors analyses were performed by partial derivation
technique. The electrical conductivity of hybrid composites was also measured with a digital four
probes resistance tester (SZ-82, Suzhou Electronic Equipment Factory) at room temperature. The
nano-Fe3O4@CFs, PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats and fabricated hybrid composites are shown in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Structural characterizations
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
The XPS spectra of the nano-Fe3O4@CFs composite fabricated by modified multi-step EPD method is represented in Fig. 3. The three main peaks of C 1s, O 1s and Fe 2p are characterized
in Fig. 3 (a). Fig. 3 (b) demonstrates the high resolution XPS spectrum of Fe 2p in which the
peaks at 710.8 and 724.4 eV are in a good agreement with that of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 of Fe3O4, respectively [42, 43]. Fig. 3 (c) depicts the high resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s which is
deconvoluted into four different peaks. The peaks at 284.3, 285.6, 286.6 and 294.8 eV can be
assigned to the C-C/C=C, C-O, C=O and O-C=O groups, respectively. These alkoxy groups can
be formed on CFs during etching with HNO3 solution.
The XRD patterns of the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 powder, nano-Fe3O4@CFs composite and PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure are shown in Fig. 4. The pattern of nano-Fe3O4 powder (Fig. 4 (a)) illustrates eight characteristic peaks at 2θ = 21.2°, 30.7°, 35.9°, 43.4°, 53.4°, 57.2°,
62.3° and 75.2° which can be scattered from (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), (440) and
(533) planes of face-centered cubic (FCC) Fe3O4, (JCPDS card no. 03-0863), respectively. The crystalline size of the as-synthesized Fe3O4 powder was calculated from (311) peak using Scherrer equation [20]:
= . (1) Where D is the crystalline size, λ is the wavelength (λ=0.154 nm for CuKα1), β is the full width of the peak at medium height (FWHM in radian) and θ is the peak position (2θ in degree). The
calculations showed that the crystalline size of as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 is 28 nm. In the XRD pattern of the nano-Fe3O4@CFs composite (Fig. 4(b)), it can be seen that the eight characteristic peaks of Fe3O4 also exist in this pattern which can verify the deposition of nano-Fe3O4 particles on CFs during EPD process. The broadened peak around 26° can be assigned to the graphitic

crystalline structure of CFs [22]. In the case of the XRD pattern of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs (Fig. 4(c)), it is hard to find strong diffraction peaks appertaining to PANI, as the diffraction
peaks of CFs and PANI are nearly centered at the same 2θ and only a broadened peak around
19.2° can be related to PANI. However, it can be noted that the existence of diffraction peaks of
the nano-Fe3O4@CFs in this XRD pattern at 30.7° and 35.9°, indicates the presence of nanoFe3O4 particles in the heterostructure after in situ polymerization process.
To further investigate the structural properties of samples, FT-IR spectroscopy was used and its
results are displayed in Fig. 5. It is well-known that one of the unwanted phases which can be
formed during the fabrication of nano-Fe3O4 is γ-Fe2O3. Because of the same crystal structure and also similar lattice parameters (a=0.83 nm for γ-Fe2O3 and a =0.84 nm for Fe3O4) of Fe3O4 and γ-Fe2O3, it is impossible to distinguish Fe3O4 from γ-Fe2O3 solely based on XRD results [44, 45]. But, the presence of a characteristic peak of Fe-O bonding at 583 cm-1 indicates that the as-
synthesized nano-Fe3O4 powder is entirely pure without any γ-Fe2O3 impurity since, in FT-IR spectra of γ-Fe2O3, this peak appears at 630 cm -1 [45, 46]. The other corresponding adsorption peaks and assigned various modes are indicated in Table 1.

Considering the Table 1 it can be concluded that, (i) the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 powder is entirely pure without any γ-Fe2O3 particles, (ii) the nitric acid treatment results in the formation of COO- functional group on CFs during the surface etching process, (iii) a layer of PANI has
completely covered the nano-Fe3O4@CFs through its in situ polymerization process.
Fig. 6 (a-d) demonstrates the FE-SEM images and Fig. 6 (e-h) shows the corresponding EDS
elemental mapping data (C (Kα1_2), Fe (Kα1) and O (Kα1)) of the nano-Fe3O4@CFs composites. As it can be observed from Fig. 6 (a-d), the nano-Fe3O4 particles have homogenously covered CFs, creating a large-scale uniform coating after applying the modified
EPD process. Also, the elemental mapping analysis verifies the presence and distribution of Fe
(Fig. 6 (f)) and O (Fig. 6 (g)) on CFs, which suggests that the nano-Fe3O4 particles were coated on CF and the nano-Fe3O4@CFs composite structure is formed. While in the case of the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure, represented in Fig. 7 (a-d), the elements N (Kα1_2, Fig. 7(g)) and Fe (Kα1, Fig. 7(h)) were identified. Element N which is attributed to PANI, is
totally distributed on nano-Fe3O4@CFs referred to FE-SEM images showed in Fig. 7 (a-d). The increased diameter of the nano-Fe3O4 coated CF from 8.29 to 12.02 µm after in situ polymerization process of PANI can also confirm the formation of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure with a layer by layer (LBL) assembly.

The morphology and particle size of the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 particles, nano-Fe3O4@CFs and PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure were investigated using HR-TEM images represented in Fig. 8 and Fig. 9, respectively. From Fig. 8 (a) it can be seen that the distance
between (311) lattice plane of the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 particles with two adjacent planes of its inverse-spinel type crystal structure is 0.25 nm which is in a good agreement with other
reports [6, 43]. Also, the selected area electron diffraction pattern (SAED) (Fig. 8 (b)) of these
particles exhibits ring patterns of inverse-spinel Fe3O4 which clearly verifies their crystalline nature. From Fig. 8 (c), it is obvious that the as-synthesized Fe3O4 particles are in nano dimensions with diameters ranging from 15 to 30 nm. In this way, the TEM observations
confirms the particle size calculations based on XRD data using Scherrer equation. Considering
Fig. 9 (a) it can be observed that the nano-Fe3O4 particles successfully deposited on CF after performing EPD. The unclear rings in SAED pattern of Fig. 9 can be attributed to the presence of
amorphous CF beside nano-Fe3O4 particles in the nano-Fe3O4@CF. Moreover, Fig. 9 (b) depicts the cross-section TEM image and SAED pattern of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure. Considering this image it can be concluded that a PANI layer has covered the surface of nano-
Fe3O4@CF and the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure is successfully formed using EPD followed by an in situ polymerization process of PANI.
The magnetic properties of samples were studied via VSM by applying a maximum magnetic
field of ±10 KOe. The typical loops of magnetic hysteresis, magnetizing field vs. magnetization,
of the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 powder, nano-Fe3O4@CFs and PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure at room temperature are depicted in Fig. 10. It can be seen that, the as-
synthesized nano-Fe3O4 particles show a near superparamagnetic behavior with the very low residual magnetization and coercivity which confirms that with the simple and economical
M
AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
chemical co-precipitation method the synthesis of high-quality nano-Fe3O4 particles is possible. Also, the nano-Fe3O4@CFs composite and also PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure narrow hysteresis loops confirms their soft ferromagnetic behavior [48].
The summarized magnetic properties such as coercivity (Hc), saturation magnetization (Ms) and residual magnetization (Mrs) of samples are also indicated in Table 2. It is obvious that the deposition of nano-Fe3O4 on CFs reduced its Ms value from 72.612 emu/g for the pure nanoFe3O4 powder to 8.934 emu/g for the nano-Fe3O4@CFs. Furthermore, covering the nanoFe3O4@CFs with a layer of PANI decreased its Ms value from 8.934 to 0.191 emu/g for the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure. All of these reductions in Ms values can be related to the decrease in the effective mass/volume percentage of nano-Fe3O4 particles in the composites with the addition of CFs and PANI.

composites

The EM wave absorption and also EMI shielding properties of the composite materials can be measured based on their magnetic and dielectric properties. The complex permeability( = ˊ − ˝), complex permittivity ( = ˊ − ˝), magnetic loss tangent ( = ˝ ˊ) and dielectric loss tangent ( = ˝ ˊ) of the epoxy-based PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composites were measured in the 8.2-18 GHz frequency range at room temperature which is shown in Fig. 11 (a-f). The real parts of permeability ( ˊ) and permittivity ( ˊ) are attributed to energy storage while the imaginary parts ( ˝ ˝) are associated with energy attenuation, because of different loss mechanisms such as resonance, eddy current (conduction losses),
polarization relaxation and etc. [42]. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), with the increase in the test frequency, the ˊ values of the epoxy-based hybrid composite containing 5 wt. % of the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs fragments decrease from 148.2 at 8.2 GHz to 72.3 at 12.6 GHz and then being stable around 72 until 18 GHz. While this
value for the sample with 1 wt. % of EM wave absorbing segments at whole the frequency range is stable around 20 with no fluctuations. The ˝ values (Fig. 11 (b)) for the sample containing 5 wt. % of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs increases below 10 GHz with a fluctuation at 9.6 GHz from 30.2 to 44.9 and then decreases slightly to 32.7 at the end, whereas in the case of the composite
with 1 wt. % absorbing segments it increases continuously from 6.2 at 8.2 GHz to 9.9 at 18 GHz. The ˊ values (Fig. 11 (c)) for the epoxy-based hybrid composite containing 5 wt. % of the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs fragments decrease from 5.1 at 8.2 GHz to 3.7 at 18 GHz with two small fluctuations at 9.2 GHz and 10.1 GHz, whereas for the composite with 1 wt. % of
absorbing fragments it is stable around 1 at whole the test frequency range with a small fluctuation around 9.7 GHz. The ˝ (Fig. 11 (d)) values of the composite with 1 wt. % of

absorbing segments are clearly higher than that for the composite with 5 wt. % absorbing
segments and it is stable around 0 with two small fluctuations at 9.7 and 10.3 GHz. While for the
composite with 5 wt. % absorbing segments it decreases continuously from -0.24 at 8.2 GHz to -
1.1 at 18 GHz with two fluctuations at 9.7 and 10.3 GHz. The magnetic and dielectric tangent
losses are shown in Fig. 11 (e). It can be seen that the values for both of the epoxy-based hybrid composites are higher than that of their values. This can be attributed to the higher amounts of dielectric EM wave absorbing components (CFs and PANI) in comparison
with magnetic EM wave absorbing part (nano-Fe3O4 particles) in both of these hybrid composites. Therefore, it can be concluded that the attenuation of EM wave energy in the epoxy-
based PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composites is mostly generated from dielectric losses in comparison with magnetic losses.
3.5. EM wave absorption and EMI shielding properties of epoxy-based
PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composites
A schematic illustration of an epoxy-based EM wave absorbing hybrid composite is shown in
Fig. 12. In this type of EM wave absorbing materials, the incident EM wave must be easily
entered into the composite with only a small portion reflected or transmitted. So, to reduce the
surface
wave reflection, the overall input wave impedance should have the highest impedance match with the free‐space wave impedance [37]. For the entered portion of the EM radiation, the inner parts should absorb the energy of wave as much as possible. The entered wave after interacting
with EM absorbing segments (in our case the nano- PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats), creates heat
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
due to the interactions of the waveʹs EM fields and with molecular and electronic structure of
absorbing materials [49].
Based on the transmission line theory, the RL of a single-layer composite backed by a perfect

As it is shown in Fig. 13 , the epoxy-based hybrid composite containing 1 wt. % of PANI@nano-
Fe3O4@CFs segments showed the highest RL value of -11.11 dB at the frequency range of 8.2– 18 GHz compared to other samples. According to the equation (3), the lower RL of other
samples can be attributed to the impedance mismatching phenomenon between the incident EM
wave and their surface, which is generated due to the variation in thickness. In addition, it is
obvious that the composites containing 5 wt. % of EM wave absorbing segments in comparison
with the samples containing 1 wt. % of absorbing segments exhibit poorer EM wave absorption
performances. Considering Fig. 11 (a) and (b) this weak EM wave absorption performance is
related to the very high permittivity of the composite containing 5 wt. % of EM wave absorbing
segments. In this regard, it is well-known that the materials with the higher electrical
conductivity typically represents higher permittivity, which can lead to a better EM wave
absorption performance especially at higher frequencies (<10 GHz) due to huge conduction

losses (eddy current losses) [6]. Nevertheless, the very high electrical conductivity and
subsequently very high permittivity is known to be harmful for EM wave absorption since it can
lead to a great EM wave reflection from the surface of the absorbing material [2]. The
relationship between electromagnetic properties and electrical conductivity of an EM wave
absorbing composite is described by the following equation [41]: 0 = ˝ ˊ = ;248 ˊ (4) In which, ; is the total effective conductivity (S/m), 8 is frequency (Hz) and is the permittivity of vacuum (8.85×10-12 C2.N-1.m-2). In this equation, the electrical conductivity varies
linearly with frequency, the loss tangent and the imaginary part of complex permittivity. The ; values (measured by four-probe testing method) of the composites containing 1 and 5 wt. % of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs segments are indicated in Fig. 14. It can be seen that the electrical conductivity of the hybrid composites filled with 5 wt. % of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs is about seven times greater than that of the composites containing 1 wt. % of these EM wave
absorbing segments. Therefore, based on these results and also the results of EM wave
absorption tests (Fig. 13), the higher electrical conductivity and consequently higher permittivity
of the hybrid composites containing 5 wt. % of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs segments can be considered as the most important reason for their relatively lower EM wave absorption
performance.

based PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composites, Debye dipolar relaxation theory (accounted

Considering the electromagnetic properties measurements (Fig. 11 (e)), besides dielectric losses,
magnetic losses also exist in the epoxy-based PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composites. Typically, the magnetic losses in EM wave absorbing materials originate from natural and
exchange resonance, domain wall movements, eddy current loss and hysteresis loss [11].
Hysteresis loss is created because of permanent magnetization and happens only in a highly
applied field, while domain wall resonance loss is common in multi-domain magnetic materials
and occurs only in the less than GHz frequencies [11]. Consequently, as well as eddy current
loss, the exchange resonance loss can exist in the epoxy-based PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composites since the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 particles are less than 100 nm. To identify the main magnetic loss mechanisms of the fabricated composites following equation is used [43]: J = ˝E ˊFK@8KL = 24 @; (9) In which, J is a symbol which represents the amount of ˝E ˊFK@8KL, d is the thickness of composite, σ is the electrical conductivity of composite and µ0 is the permeability of vacuum (1.25 × 10-6 m.kg.s-2.A-2). The variations of J values with increasing frequency is demonstrated in Fig. 16. Based on the above-mentioned equation, if eddy current loss is the only source of magnetic losses in this composite, the J values must be constant when the frequency is changed. This is known as the skin-effect criterion [11]. Considering Fig. 16, it is clear that the J values for the epoxy-based PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composites are not constant with

a huge fluctuation around 10 GHz. So, it can be concluded that the main magnetic losses are
originated from both of the eddy current losses and also the natural resonance in this composite.
The natural resonance in the frequency range of 8.2-10 GHz can be related to the effects of
Fe3O4 particles nano size. In this regard, the natural resonance equation for ferromagnetic materials is described by following equations [43]: 248 = NOP (10) OP = 4|RL|3 S (11) In which, N is the gyromagnetic constant, OP is the energy of anisotropy and |RL| is the coefficient of anisotropy. It is well-known that the anisotropy energy of nano-sized materials,
would be intensively improved because of the surface anisotropic field by the small size effect
[43]. Therefore, the enhanced EM wave absorption properties of fabricated hybrid composites
can be related to their higher anisotropy energy which is known to be helpful for EM wave
absorption performance [43].
Another key factor which affects the EM wave absorption of a composite is its effective
absorption bandwidth. Effective absorption bandwidth is a frequency range with the minimum
RL of -10 dB [7]. In this region, more than 90% of incident EM wave can be effectively
absorbed. As it was shown in Fig. 13, the epoxy-based PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composite filled with 1 wt. % of absorbing segments with the thickness of 1.5 mm has an
effective absorption bandwidth of about 6 GHz which is more than that of other CFs based EM
wave absorbing composites which are reported by other researchers and listed in Table 4. This

to the modifications in architecture between nano-Fe3O4@CFs and PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs which contributes to the enhanced EM wave absorption of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs since, as reported in literature, the double-layered or multilayered structure can appropriately absorb EM
radiation [14, 50-53]. As it is demonstrated in Fig. 17, in the case of the uncoated CF, the
reflection is very high as CF is conductive with a huge dielectric loss. Considering Fig. 11,
PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs exhibits both of the complex permittivity and permeability, which means that the EM wave reflection from its surface is less than that for pure CF. Also, interfaces
can reflect the EM wave. Consequently, the double interfaces in PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs increases the transmission length of EM wave in the absorbing material which leads to more
energy attenuation compared to nano-Fe3O4@CFs and pure CF.

Where, S12 and S21 are scattering parameters which are associated with the transmitted part of the received EM wave from back of the absorbing composite (Fig. 12).
Fig. 18 indicates the EMI SE of the epoxy-based PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composites with different content of absorbing segments and thicknesses in the 8.2-18 GHz frequency range.
It is evident that the EMI SE of composites containing 5 wt. % of absorbing segments is higher
than that for the composites filled with 1 wt. % of absorbing segments. Considering equation
(12) and also measured electrical conductivity of these samples (Fig. 14), the improved EMI SE
performance of the hybrid composites containing 5 wt. % of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs segments can be attributed to their higher electrical conductivity. Furthermore, it can be observed that the
thicker composites exhibit obviously better EMI SE compared with thinner ones. This may be
related to the low transmission of EM wave from the composites with higher thicknesses.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructure was successfully fabricated by a twostep process. At first, the nano-Fe3O4 particles were deposited on CFs using a modified multistep EPD process. Then, in situ polymerization process of PANI was conducted on nano-Fe3O4 coated CFs to obtain PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats. The structural investigations showed that the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats have a LBL assembly. The studies on magnetic properties indicated that the saturation magnetization of nano-Fe3O4 particles was decreased from 72.612 to 0.191 emu/g for the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats. The EM properties measurements represented that in the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats both of the dielectric and magnetic wave attenuation mechanisms acting together which are essential for enhanced EM wave absorption
applications. The investigations on EM wave absorption of epoxy-based PANI@nano-
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composites revealed that the maximum RL values of the composite filled with 1 wt. % of EM wave absorbing segments with a thickness of 1.5mm was -11.11 dB with an
effective absorption bandwidths of about 6 GHz. The EMI SE of the hybrid composite filled with
5 wt. % of absorbing segments and thickness of 3 mm was measured to be about 29 dB at the
frequency range of 8.2-18 GHz. This result verifies that the epoxy-based PANI@nano-
Fe3O4@CFs hybrid composite can be used as an appropriate material in high-performance EM wave absorbing composites with a relatively thin thickness.

metadata.abstractText: In this work, a three phase carbon fiber (CF)-based electromagnetic (EM) wave absorbing and EM interference (EMI) shielding heterostructure was fabricated through a layer by layer assembly. The nano-Fe3O4 particles were deposited on CFs via a modified multi-step electrophoretic deposition (EPD). The PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs heterostructures were prepared using an in situ polymerization process of polyaniline (PANI) on nano-Fe3O4@CFs in HCl solution. The results showed that the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats with a layer by layer (LBL) assembly were successfully fabricated. The saturated magnetization (Ms) of the as-synthesized nano-Fe3O4 powder decreased from 72.612 emu/g to 8.934 emu/g for the nano-Fe3O4@CFs and ∗ E-mail address of corresponding author: faridmovy@gmail.com Tel&fax: +982182884390 M AN US CR IP T AC CE PT ED ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 2 from 8.934 emu/g to 0.191 emu/g for the PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs mats due to the reduction in the effective mass/volume percentage of nano-Fe3O4 particles in the composites. The fabricated epoxy-based hybrid composites filled with PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs segments exhibited both of the dielectric and magnetic losses at the 8.2-18 GHz frequency range. The composite containing 1 wt.% of PANI@nano-Fe3O4@CFs with the thickness of 1.5 mm showed a maximum reflection loss (RL) value of -11.11 dB with an effective absorption bandwidth of about 6 GHz in the frequency range of 8.2-18 GHz. Also, the sample filled with 5 wt. % of EM wave absorbing segments with the thickness of 3 mm demonstrated an EMI shielding effectiveness (SE) value of 29 dB at the same frequency range.
